item.title: US Plans Wider China Tech Sanctions With Subsidiary Crackdown
item.description: The Trump administration plans to broaden restrictions on China’s tech sector with new regulations to capture subsidiaries of companies under US curbs.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: A wafer on display at the Semicon China expo in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The expo runs through March 22.

item.title: Key Republican Hopes ‘Revenge’ Tax Will Be a Never-Used Deterrent
item.description: A key House Republican tax negotiator said he hopes the so-called “revenge” measure in President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill targeting foreign investors will be a deterrent that is never deployed.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: The rotunda at the US Capitol in Washington DC, US, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. The White House amped up the pressure on Republicans on Wednesday urging lawmakers to quickly approve President Donald Trump’s signature tax bill, adding that a failure to do so would be the “ultimate betrayal.”

item.title: Supreme Court Clears Trump to Strip 500,000 of Legal Status
item.description: The Supreme Court let the Trump administration immediately strip the legal right to temporarily live and work in the US from as many as half a million people from Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Trump Says China ‘Totally Violated’ Trade Agreement With US
item.description: US President Donald Trump accused China of violating an agreement with the US to ease tariffs, ratcheting up tensions between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: A container ship approaches the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai.

item.title: Former Education Secretary Warns of Innovation ‘Disaster’ Amid Higher Ed Attacks
item.description: Former US Education Secretary John King Jr. warned that President Donald Trump’s efforts to strip major research universities of federal funding could lead to a lasting regression in innovation and a loss of top talent.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: John King Jr., senior advisor at the U.S. Department of Education, speaks during a news conference with U.S. President Barack Obama, not pictured, in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Friday, Oct. 2, 2015. Obama announced that Education Secretary Arne Duncan is stepping down in December and will be replaced by Deputy Secretary John B. King Jr.

item.title: Court Setbacks on Tariffs Rob Trump of a Prized Asset: Leverage
item.description: For months, President Donald Trump has boasted that his most sweeping tariffs amount to powerful leverage to win trade concessions from Beijing to Brussels.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Operations at the Port of Trieste in Italy.

item.title: Musk’s Drug Use on Campaign Trail Stoked Concerns, NYT Says
item.description: Elon Musk was using drugs more heavily than previously known while on the campaign trail to help elect Donald Trump president, worrying some people close to the mercurial billionaire, the New York Times reported.
item.dc:creator: Rick Clough

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk speaks during a town hall in Lancaster, Pennsylvania, on Oct. 26.

item.title: Tariff Revenues Rise Sharply in Canada After Retaliation Against Trump Levies
item.description: A spike in custom import duties shows proceeds from retaliatory tariffs are starting to roll into the coffers of Canada’s federal government.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Trucks at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario.

item.title: Czech Justice Minister Resigns Over $45 Million Gift in Bitcoin
item.description: Czech Justice Minister Pavel Blazek resigned amid criticism that his ministry accepted a gift in Bitcoin from a convicted criminal and later sold the cryptocurrency for about 1 billion koruna ($45 million).
item.dc:creator: Andrea Dudik

media:content.media:description: Pavel Blazek

item.title: Trump Is Canceling $3.7 Billion in Clean Energy Projects
item.description: The Energy Department is canceling some $3.7 billion in government support for clean energy projects it said did not warrant continued backing from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Hydrogen tanks in a storage area at a nuclear station in Scriba, New York.

item.title: Cooking Gas Shortage in Cuba Fuels Electric Demand, Deepening Energy Crisis
item.description: Top Cuban officials took to the airwaves as a shortage of cooking gas on the communist-run island prompted an unusual spike in electricity demand that’s now exacerbating blackouts.
item.dc:creator: Jim Wyss

media:content.media:description: Residents use lights on their phone during a blackout in Havana on March 14. Photographer: Yamil Lage/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Erdogan Backs Turkey Economy Plan But Repeats Distaste for Rates
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan reiterated his opposition to interest rates while endorsing the country’s orthodox economic program, which relies on high borrowing costs to curb inflation.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman, Firat Kozok

media:content.media:description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan

item.title: Congress Could Unravel Biden’s Climate Law. Here’s What to Watch.
item.description: How Republicans want to remake the Inflation Reduction Act.
item.dc:creator: Todd Woody, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: House Speaker Mike Johnson speaks to the media after the House passed a giant tax and spending bill at the US Capitol on May 22.

item.title: US Transport Department Pauses Planned Workforce Cuts Due to Litigation
item.description: The US Transportation Department said it’s pausing planned cuts to its workforce while it waits for resolution in pending legal battles over the Trump administration’s efforts to significantly reduce the size of the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille

media:content.media:description: The Department of Transportation headquarters in Washington, DC.

item.title: Macron Urges China to Stop North Korea From Deploying in Europe
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron urged China to prevent its ally North Korea from joining Russia’s war of aggression against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron during the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore May 30.

item.title: Hochul and Murphy Break Ground on $10 Billion NYC Bus Hub
item.description: New York Governor Kathy Hochul and New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy broke ground Thursday on a $10 billion redevelopment of Manhattan’s bus terminal, the busiest in the world.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy and New York Governor Kathy Hochul attend the ground breaking for a new Midtown Bus Terminal on May 29, 2025 in New York City. The 10-year, $10 billion project replaces the decades-old Port Authority Bus Terminal.

item.title: DOGE Funding Cuts Prove Fleeting for Groups That Ditch DEI Words
item.description: After losing $60 million in federal funding, a pair of national housing groups made strategic edits to their websites — and got it back.
item.dc:creator: Emily Flitter

media:content.media:description: Construction at the Willows at Valley Run, an affordable housing development in Coatesville, Pennsylvania, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 28, 2024. The economy is on the upswing in Philadelphia and its suburbs after several years of pandemic-related weakness, but local Democratic leaders say Biden and the party need to do more to persuade voters that his administration deserves credit for the rebound.

item.title: Reeves Nominates UK OBR Chief Richard Hughes for Reappointment
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves nominated Richard Hughes to serve a second term as head of the Office for Budget Responsibility, Britain’s powerful fiscal watchdog.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Richard Hughes Photographer: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

item.title: Russia to Attend Fresh Talks as Ukraine Demands Peace Proposals
item.description: Russia said it’s sending a delegation to Istanbul Monday for a second round of talks with Ukraine amid last-minute wrangling over Kyiv’s insistence that Moscow outline its peace proposals before any meeting.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Volodymyr Verbianyi

media:content.media:description: The site of a Russian missile attack in Kyiv, on May 25.

item.title: What If Independent Regulators Are No Longer Independent?
item.description: In a test of a 90-year-old court decision, Trump is attempting to rein in US agencies that oversee everything from securities to cigarette lighters.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

item.title: BBC to Pay Gerry Adams 100,000 Euros in Defamation Case
item.description: The BBC has been ordered to pay former Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams 100,000 (£84,000) after he won a "resounding" libel victory over the broadcaster.

media:content.media:description: Gerry Adams. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Tariff Ruling Threatens a $2 Trillion Fiscal Hole in Trump Plan
item.description: The court ruling that blocked much of President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs threatens to blow what some economists estimate as a $2 trillion hole into the US fiscal outlook over the coming decade, should the judgment stay in place.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Treasury Department building in front of the White House.

item.title: India Toughens Stance in US Trade Talks After Courts Weigh In
item.description: India will urge the US to drop all the tariffs imposed on April 2 as it adopts a tougher negotiating stance in the wake of legal challenges to President Donald Trump’s signature trade policy, people with knowledge of the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava, Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes load a container ship at the Mundra Port of Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: German Minister Eyes New Digital Tax as US Prepares Pushback
item.description: A junior member of German Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s cabinet proposed a new tax on internet platforms like Alphabet Inc.’s Google and Meta Platforms Inc.’s Facebook, a move that could stoke further trade tensions with the US.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz, left, and Wolfram Weimer, right.

item.title: Lula Disapproval Rises as Scandal Feeds Corruption Concerns
item.description: President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s disapproval rating rose in May as a burgeoning social security scandal helped turn corruption into Brazilians’ top concern.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: In US-China Trade War, Latin America Takes Sides With Beijing
item.description: In the tit-for-tat trade war between the US and China, Latin America is siding with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati

item.title: Trump’s Tax Bill Has Nasty Surprise in SALT Fine Print for Some Rich Americans
item.description: House Republicans’ “big, beautiful bill” could bring hundreds of billions of dollars in tax cuts to wealthy business owners.
item.dc:creator: Ben Steverman

media:content.media:description: US House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican from Louisiana, right, and US President Donald Trump after attending a House Republican caucus meeting at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. Trump on Tuesday pushed back on demands from Republicans who have threatened to sink his giant tax bill if the legislation does not significantly boost the state and local tax deduction, lawmakers said.

item.title: Canada Defends Golden Dome, Reaffirms Military Ties With US
item.description: Canada reaffirmed its close military ties with the US and spoke in support of President Donald Trump’s proposed “Golden Dome” missile defense system, which Ottawa is thinking about joining.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Jennie Carignan

item.title: UK Considers Forcing Households to Fill Out Key Economic Surveys
item.description: UK officials are probing the legal and practical implications of forcing households to fill out key economic surveys after a collapse in responses left the Bank of England in the dark over jobs data crucial to its interest-rate decisions.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Zambia Proposes Increased Number of Lawmakers as Elections Loom
item.description: Zambia plans to boost the number of elected members of parliament by more than a third, raising the prospect of a higher government wage bill at a time when the state is trying to conclude a debt-restructuring process.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: Hakainde Hichilema Photographer: Bernd von Jutrczenka/picture alliance/Getty Images
